theText: Wednesday, 5 April 2000 MAIN COMMITTEE 15345 Wednesday, 5 April 2000 ----Social Security: Welfare Benefits to the social security system highlighted in the recent welfare reform report released by the Minister for Family and Community Services, Jocelyn Newman. This report has generated considerable interest in my electorate and, one would imagine, in everyone else’s electorate as well. I want to place on record part of a letter written to me by Phil Nichol of Lymington who, on hearing the minister’s comments on Radio National, wrote to me as follows: Anyway my feelings and those of others I know were one of optimism and I would hazard a guess that many people who feel left out of the prosperity of this present society felt good about what they heard. Most people receiving benefits and even low income earners hope others in society want to share in mutual obligation and social cohesion. Most recipients of benefits, no matter what type, I am sure would welcome organized community involvement but NOT if it is portrayed in a negative fashion, if there is stigma attached to the work, if it is seen in any way like a punitive measure, if there is resentment in the air and if it is not flexible and chosen in some way by the participant. Many people on benefits live busy exciting useful lives even with small amounts of cash. If people on small incomes pay little tax that will also be rectified after July when benefit recipients too will be GST taxed. Senator Newman on 29/3/00 indicated that Centrelink in the past has portrayed an abrupt noninclusive type of front. The new Centrelink would be different. Personally I have always found individuals in Centrelink very nice-its what the people working there have been asked to carry out. To my thinking her comments the next day ... seemed to backtrack from the 29/3/00. The whole feeling of trust, fellowship and furtherance seemed now to be at odds with comments the previous day. She seemed political and divisive. Imagine thinking low income earners would be glad that those receiving benefits would be obliged to do their dues. Why did she pick LOW INCOME EARNERS? Why not the rich, say those on $1 million a year, would those people also not feel glad of mutual obligation? This welfare reform must: have no stigma of a negative kind attached to benefit recipients; have no negative stigma attached to the type of work they do; they, mutual obligers, should not be ‘told’ what to do but should in agreement with a broad selection of community members choose the work they do for the benefit of all; it must be flexible. N.B. Benefit recipients might even be able to do or help with some of the work low income earners do then we can all be friends together bettering our communities. Regional Forest Agreements: Victoria west RFA outcome in Victoria. The Victorian timber industry can now get on with the job of attracting new investment and value adding. There were a number of important aspects in these RFA negotiations. Firstly, there will be no net job losses as a result of the final two RFAs in Victoria. I am very pleased that we are going to achieve that. The Commonwealth and state governments together are providing a package of $42.6 million under the Commonwealth-Victorian Hardwood Timber Industry Development Restructuring Program to help businesses take advantage of RFA certainty and adjust to changes in resource availability. theText: I want to speak briefly this morning about the successful15346 MAIN COMMITTEE Wednesday, 5 April 2000 bulk of this funding will be for industry development and value-adding projects. The program also provides a safety net for businesses and workers. This brings the available cash under lion from the state of Victoria. A further $20 million is committed by the Victorian government to silviculture and plantation initiatives, improved inventories and tourism development. The resource reductions that were part of the RFA will be phased in over two years which will help the value-adding projects get off the ground. The conservation outcomes are also outstanding in Victoria. More than half of the total public land across all five RFA regions is now protected in the comprehensive adequate and representative-CARreserve system. Overall in Victoria, 68 per cent of all old-growth forest in the five RFA regions are in reserves. In west Victoria the RFA adds about 194,000 hectares to existing reserves. This brings the total CAR reserve amount to 633,000 hectares, which means that 65 per cent of the region’s public land is now set aside for conservation. Significant additions to reserves include the Pyrete Range in the Wombat State Forest, which is added to the Lerderderg State Park, and Tallageira, which becomes a nature conservation reserve. I would like to pay significant tribute to both Minister Tuckey and Minister Garbutt in Victoria, who I think had very sensible discussions in relation to a very difficult issue. Also, there has always been a strong relationship between Minister Tuckey and the union movement in Victoria, who have worked very hard to protect the interests of their workers in conjunction with both the federal and state governments. In the 30 seconds remaining to me, I would like to talk about the behaviour of the Department of Natural Resources in Victoria. The difficulty with this RFA was very much to do with a significantly reduced sustainable yield figure which was brought out late last year. Everyone involved in the industry had been relying on the figures of the state department. This is not a political comment; it is a comment about the state department, which had been telling us that all was well and then it turned out that it was not. This has caused enormous difficulties. (Time expired) Swan Electorate: Road Safety Initiative tiative that is operating in my electorate of Swan which targets primary school students. This initiative was started last year because we felt that young people returning to school needed to be made fully aware of road safety issues. We needed to look at issues such as how they could safely ride their bikes, skateboards and rollerblades. If they were having to cross streets on their way to school, we needed to make sure that they could do so safely, without being hit by vehicles. We looked at implementing a road safety competition. We involved local primary schools. We approached the principals and asked for their support and we found that that support was quite overwhelming. We talked to parent groups and found that they believed there was a real need to teach young people about road safety issues. Of course, we talked to the young people themselves and asked them what they believed would be a good way of getting them to become aware of road safety issues. We also approached an organisation called Constable Care. Constable Care in Western Australia is a child safety program. They run a whole raft of programs dealing with the whole issue of child safety-stranger danger issues, road safety and a whole raft of activities aimed at ensuring that children are protected. When we came up with the competition we thought we would need to have two groups of primary school students, so we looked at grades 1 to 4 and decided that we would introduce a drawing competition for them, whereby they would have to do a drawing on road safety and include a number of different points-which I will cover later. theText: I would like to bring to the attention of the House a road safety iniWednesday, 5 April 2000 MAIN COMMITTEE 15347 being in that older category, we thought it would be appropriate for them to write an essay on road safety. We asked the representatives from Constable Care to judge all the entries. We asked the young people to look, in their drawings and essays, at the issues of children wearing bicycle helmets, children on skateboards et cetera, wearing protective pads, and children using the term ‘stop, look and listen’ when crossing the road in order to ensure their safety. We asked them to illustrate crosswalk attendants in their drawings to show that they knew that the crosswalk was where they needed to go to cross the road on their way to school. We also asked them to mention or include a picture of Constable Care and to mention their school so that we could promote the activities of the school in supporting parents. I am pleased to say that we have received hundreds of entries. The program has been extremely successful. I commend the program to the House. If any member would like some more information on what we have done, I will be pleased to provide it. Aged Care: Riverside Nursing Home the member for Isaacs, Mr Wilton, in the House yesterday, particularly in relation to the Riverside Nursing Home and the Minister for Aged Care, Mrs Bronwyn Bishop. I would like to quote from an article in the Australian of 18 March 2000 by Amanda Hodge. She quotes the St Vincent’s aged care chief executive, Kerrie Cross. The article stated that initially: Relatives feared that moving Melbourne’s Riverside Nursing Home residents would kill them. But just 10 days after the move, nursing staff say the improvement shown by some of them is so remarkable they are comparing it to the restoration of the senses depicted in the Robert De Niro movie Awakenings. Kerrie Cross stated: ‘What we found is most of them were either overmedicated or receiving inappropriate medication ... We did expect residents to improve once they settled down, but we’ve seen some remarkable transformations in the health and well-being of residents, and relatives have commented on that.’ From all that Ms Cross has already seen, there is no doubt in her mind that despite the initial trauma it caused, federal Aged Care Minister Bronwyn Bishop did the right thing by revoking the Riverside proprietors’ licence. Joe West, 64, is equally convinced. Eighteen months ago he entered Riverside to help mend a broken hip and in that time he developed such horrific foot ulcers, ‘the size of CDs’, that he could barely walk. Now on the mend and one of only a few residents not suffering some degree of dementia, he regularly takes himself down in the lifts of St Vincent’s for a cigarette and some sunshine. Like many of the former Riverside residents, Joe has no idea where he will go from here. All he knows is, even if the Riverside proprietors do have their licence reinstated, he never wants to go back. And for the benefit of those opposite I would like to repeat the fact that all he knows is that even if the Riverside proprietors do have their licences reinstated, he never wants to go back. For the benefit of the member for Isaacs, I believe a few facts need to be incorporated into Hansard. The government’s aged care reforms are designed to improve the quality of care and the vast majority of the ‘good’ facilities are getting on with the business of providing high quality care and services. The poor performers are now under scrutiny and the media are highlighting this fact. This is a sign that the system of ensuring quality care in residential facilities is working. It is not simply a matter of closing a home. We must protect the health and well-being of the very frail people in the home and, if one is closed, find suitable accommodation elsewhere. It is only with the most careful consideration and planning that we would move residents. (Time expired)

speaker: Mrs Draper (Makin)
theText: I would like to take this opportunity to refute comments made by15348 MAIN COMMITTEE Wednesday, 5 April 2000 Veterans: Far East Strategic Reserve of the House, I have pointed out to the government the injustices that arise from anomalies in terms of eligibility for some categories of repatriation benefits for Australian former servicemen who served in various theatres throughout South-East Asia over the last 40 years or so, most specifically naval personnel associated with the Far East Strategic Reserve during the Emergency in what was then Malaya in the late 1950s and early 1960s. Several years ago, the Minister for Veterans' Affairs did provide some limited relief to these veterans in terms of repatriation benefits. However, he failed at that stage to rectify the most substantial anomaly, which was denying the former RAN personnel access to service pensions which Army and RAAF personnel from the same theatre are entitled to. Really, the only justification that was ever offered for failing to correct that anomaly was a lot of legalistic mumbo jumbo that seemed to come out of the bureaucracy. Last year, in May 1999, the minister announced a review of these matters and appointed Major General Mohr and Rear Admiral Kennedy to carry out a review of anomalies in respect of South-East Asian service. I will read a couple of paragraphs of that review. The key aspect is the recommendation that is now before the government: It is recommended that such anomalyThat is, the anomaly in respect of service pensionshould be removed by placing naval seagoing personnel serving with FESR in the period 01 July 1955 to 31 July 1960 on the same basis as other members of FESR and in particular, to grant them qualifying service so that they will be eligible for the Service pension. The review makes the point that seagoing naval personnel formed part of the RAN contingent to the British Commonwealth Far East Strategic Reserve. These personnel have never been eligible for repatriation benefits until 1997. In 1997, the government accepted a recommendation that their service be classified as operational service. Ex-service personnel organisations representing the interests of seagoing naval personnel, however, continued to press for the period of service to count as qualifying service for the service pension. The minister now has this recommendation from the review he has commissioned before him. The recommendations are quite clear. I must indicate that the review is a little late; the minister expected it in October last year, but in due course it has arrived in February this year. He really now has no justification for failing to correct the long standing injustice. East Timor: Support for Service Families Workplace Relations and Small Business)-Last week I found myself in Darwin on my parliamentary duties and I had great pleasure in catching up with an old unit that I served with, the 5th/7th Battalion, Royal Australian Regiment. I only caught up with one of the officers because the unit is in Timor at the moment. They have been over there for seven months and they return on 3 May. I rise today in the Main Committee to commend the 5/7 RAR pit crew. The pit crew are the ladies who are supporting their husbands whilst they are overseas. All the attention-and rightly so-goes to the service personnel who are obviously doing a great job in Timor. But quite often we forget that the family members left behind have to carry on, run households and look after the children, and they need a great deal of support. I believe the CO’s wife, Patti Jane Gould, instigated the very first pit crew, as she called it, and appointed a committee which was brought from all ranks-no rank-specific involvement at all. This committee was headed by Mrs Rebecca Tufekic, who I believe has done an absolutely fabulous job in keep-

speaker: Mr Brough (Longman
theText: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Employment,Wednesday, 5 April 2000 MAIN COMMITTEE 15349 ing up the morale of the wives, the girlfriends and the families during the seven-month absence of their loved ones. They have run a number of functions. They have produced continual newsletters. They have actually had their own operations room set up in battalion headquarters. I am led to believe that they could well be doing a better job than some of their husbands. In fact, that is what they are trying to lead me to believe. Perhaps their husbands, when they return, may find themselves out of a job. There have been some very important aspects to their job because, as you can appreciate, in all walks of life we all have little crises that crop up from time to time, and not having the husband or the boyfriend around can obviously lead to greater distress. They have set up welfare phones lines so that they know where the soldiers are at any particular time, what operation they are on and when the mail is likely to be getting through. One quick story that was relayed to me was that each of the soldiers gets five minutes every week to ring home. This has been set up through Optus and it is a great initiative. One particular fellow rang home to find that home was not there any more. That was his first fiveminute call and, obviously, there was a bit of concern. The following week he rang his mother-in-law-for five minutes-who told him where his wife now was. So three weeks later, on the third five-minute phone call, he finally found where his wife had been relocated to. It was all fine, it was all above board, but can you imagine the angst for a soldier in the field having to wait an additional week to get a five-minute phone call. It was here that the members of the pit crew were able to come in and support the families on the ground. I would also like to add congratulations to the two assistant adjutants, Lieutenant Paul Greive and Lieutenant Damien Kook, who both, I am told, have done a fabulous job in maintaining the morale of the battalion. They are due back in Darwin on 3 May. I am sure all of Darwin wishes them well and will give them a welcome return. A NEW TAX SYSTEM (FAMILY ASSISTANCE AND RELATED MEASURES) BILL 2000 Second Reading Debate resumed from 9 March, on motion by Mr Anthony: That the bill be now read a second time. Assistance and Related Measures) Bill 2000. This bill forms part of the government’s overall tax package and is all about how this bill is going to interact with the GST, family payments and a whole range of payments that families are going to get. That leads me, quite clearly, to talk about where the family is in today’s society. The family is the backbone, the centre, of everything we do in this country. The family is that unit in our society which really holds us all together. It is really about what keeps us going, and it is the part that the government should be placing the most importance on to be able to deliver something positive. This is where this bill absolutely fails, because there is no way in the world that there is anything in this bill that looks to build on the family or to assist the family or to somehow compensate or make life easier in relation to the huge impost that the GST will have on families. Families are a changing composition in our society. What was previously seen as the nuclear family has changed somewhat today. We are finding that more people are choosing to have fewer children, and there is probably a variety of reasons why that is the case. But it is clearly evident that today there are just not many people deciding to have three or more children. In fact, more couples are deciding to have only one child or to have no children at all. There is almost a trend developing. Australia is becoming a childless society. I think part of the reason for that is that people are actually struggling and finding it more difficult to make ends meet. They are finding that to have a family is actually a huge burden. There is not just
title: Representatives Main Committee

speaker: Mr Ripoll (Oxley) (9.58 A.m.)
theText: I rise today to speak on the A New Tax System (Family15350 MAIN COMMITTEE Wednesday, 5 April 2000 the financial burden; there are all sorts of other burdens. Government policies are not family friendly-they are very much antifamily. If we have a close look at this bill, what we will find is a whole raft of antifamily policies. Every single one of them is part and parcel of the antifamily policies of this government. If we have a look at the GST to start with, we can see that the whole GST is based on consumption. Who consumes more? Is it the upwardly mobile yuppie living on his own in a nice unit in the North Shore of Sydney, or is it the family with three children? Who has the most disposable income? Who actually consumes more in terms of disposable income? It is the family. The family with two or three children actually suffers. They are the ones who have less opportunity for work because they have children to care for, so they cannot do the overtime. They are the ones who have bigger costs when they go shopping. They are the ones who actually carry the burden for the high income earners. That is what this policy is all about. But it goes much further and much deeper than that. We have all talked a lot about the costs and the problems associated with the GST for the family, but what about education? How does GST impact on education? We are all told that education is GST free. I beg to differ. I do not think it is GST free at all. I think education has a huge GST component to it, but I will have a look at that in a minute. If we look at health, who is it that pays the majority of the health cost? Is it the single person living in a unit on the North Shore of Sydney? No, it is the family. They are the ones that have to take the children to hospital. They are the ones that are being forced, through legislation, to have to take up private health insurance. So when I say that this government’s policies are all antifamily, I am quite serious about that because every single area you turn to, every place you look at, every policy that this government has is antifamily. In particular, the A New Tax System (Family Assistance and Related Measures) Bill 2000 that is before the House is actually very much antifamily. I think we need to take a new approach. It is time that this government and all governments looked very carefully at what government policy is doing to families. There needs to be a new approach, an approach that says, ‘We support families. We will do that not just through rhetoric, but we will do it through our policies. We will actually give you something concrete. We will give you family assistance that means something. So that if you want to go from welfare to work, then you actually have an incentive through government policy,’ not a disincentive. That is what this policy is about-disincentives for people to go from welfare to work. I talk to people all the time who come to my office and say, ‘I would love to be able to go out and do a little bit more, but if I go out and I try to do a bit of overtime to give my family a little bit extra, the government slugs me. Not only am I slugged through tax, but I am slugged through family assistance.’ So it is always a double whammy. Now, for the first time in this country, we are about to see the triple whammy take place. Not only are families going to be slugged on tax, not only are they going to be slugged on family assistance, they are about to be slugged with the GST as well. On1 July the triple whammy hits, because on 1 July they will also carry the new burden in this country that is squarely being shouldered by all the families. It will be low and middle income families that will carry the load. It is not going to be a burden on the people earning $50,000, $60,000, $70,000, $80,000 or $90,000 a year. They are going to be better off. So if they are not carrying the burden, who is? Who is going to be carrying the burden for this country in the future under a supposedly new tax system for a new century? That is quite easy to answer-it will be families. Again, when I say that this bill and this government’s policies are antifamily, I am quite serious about it because everywhere I look I see only antifamily policies. The government also talks a lot about what we might do in terms of education. There is talk of literacy and a whole heap of things, but there is very little talk in terms of money going back to families through early intervention programs and trying to do something positive. You do not see too much money going to early intervention programs. You do not see too much Wednesday, 5 April 2000 MAIN COMMITTEE 15351 money going to programs that will assist people and take them from where they are today and give them a hand up, or just a bit of assistance. Rather, you see measures that are designed to create more bureaucracies, and more measures that are designed to move the goalposts just a little bit further every time, just to make it that little bit more difficult. There is a raft of things in here, which I will talk about shortly, that actually covers that. The government also claims that inflation will be only 1.9 per cent-and it made a very big issue at the last election about that. This was the key to compensation packages and to selling this policy and legislation to the people. We all know that that is absolutely incorrect. The 1.9 per cent was probably blown on the first day. It is just not the case. Try about five per cent. Try a little bit more. What are we seeing today? What is the evidence we have right before us? If you pick up Choice magazine, they say, ‘You might be $3 better off with your shopping.’ I do not agree with them. I do not think that is true at all. I and a lot of other people have actually been doing a price watch survey out there to monitor the cost of a fairly reasonable standard basket of goods, not after GST, but right now. What has been the cost over the last nine or 12 months? Let me tell you. Since this government has put forward its policies, there has been a steady increase, an inflationary rise based on the expectation that GST will cause prices to go up, and not just in the services or goods sector where we know GST will be applied but also on things that have no GST, such as basic foods, milk and bread. I was shocked to see some of the results that have come out of that price watch over the last six months. What we have seen is what I would describe as some people taking the opportunity to actually raise prices and increment them slowly. That is all fine and well-1.9 per cent means absolutely nothing to most people because 1.9 per cent does not represent anything to do with reality and the real costs. If you talk to a family about their real costs-what it costs them to survive week to week, because for a lot of them it is just survival-you will see the real picture, and that 1.9 per cent soon means absolutely nothing. What does the government do? It claims that raising a child under the GST will cost an extra 30c a week. I cannot even begin to imagine where that statement or a figure like 30c a week would come in because, through my own calculations, I can tell you now that it is not 30c. If we talked dollars, we would start getting closer to the figure. It will not be cents. It will be dollars and it will be big dollars-double-digit dollars. That extra cost has already occurred since 1998 and we have not even got to 1 July as yet. It is ridiculous for the government to make all these claims about how the GST is somehow miraculously going to put some money in your back pocket. There is going to be no extra money in your back pocket. You are going to end up with a lot less. This bill is called ‘family assistance’. It is not family assistance, it is family dis-assistance. It is family anti-assistance. It is family anything but assistance. All the measures that are contained in this bill are about keeping people on welfare and keeping people down. There is nothing in here about giving people a hand up. It is almost about punishment. There is talk in this bill about zero tolerance. There is talk in this bill about a whole range of things, but there is nothing in here that says, ‘We are going to try and move people out of welfare traps and give them a hand up.’ It is just not in here. There is nothing in here about trying to help a parent who is unemployed and give them more incentives. None of that is contained in here. The recent welfare reform interim report recognised a number of problems contained in this bill, in particular the way the antifamily Youth Allowance interacts with family tax benefits. The report actually stated that this is: ... an extreme case where tight and poorly integrated social security income tests can severely discourage workforce participation. People who have looked at this quite closely actually concur that this is not about encouragement, it is not about existence, it is actually quite the opposite. Over a period of 15352 MAIN COMMITTEE Wednesday, 5 April 2000 time we have become used to the fact, as my good colleague and friend, the member for Port Adelaide, has said on quite a number of occasions, that this is a government that uses newspeak, the language of government in 2000-that is to say, more is less and less is more. That is what this is about: more is less, less is more. It is amazing-and this is coming through in a whole range of government policies and bills-that somehow by giving you less the government is actually being good to you and giving you more. love. It is all about less being more. The government claims in the interim report that, once again, this is all about families. I dispute that completely. It is all about punishing families. It really reinforces-and this is what concerns me-at a deeper level, I suppose, the long-term effects. This policy is antichildren. It is about childless societies. That is what we are pushing. That is where these policies are going. It might sound a little out there to make those sorts of comments, but what are the long-term effects when you look at the trend in today’s statistics? There is a statistic out there that says something like, ‘If you have three children in your family, you represent only 17 per cent of the community.’ I have three children, and I can tell you now that having three children is wonderful, that it is fantastic. It is great to have a family, but there are not too many policies out there that would actually encourage you. When I talk to my friends they say that I am crazy. They say that my wife and I are mad and that we are totally different from the rest of the community in that everyone else is having only one child. They ask, ‘Why would you have more children when you cannot afford it as one of you would have to give up work?’ They say that a family with one working parent is finding it more and more difficult to survive. So where does family assistance come in in this bill? Nowhere. It is nowhere at all, because there is nothing in this bill that actually encourages a family to either stay a family or become a family. This bill discourages families, it discourages people having children. When we start talking about the backbone of society, what Australia is about and how we are all about families, I would like to see that backed up by a little bit of policy that actually supports it. I would also like to see it backed up with a reversal in trends. Somewhere down the track we actually have to look at the much deeper problem that exists. What we are also seeing in this bill which is extremely disturbing is the new income estimates rule. This is very disturbing in the way that low and middle income families can incur debts. You are required by Centrelink to actually go in there on a fortnightly basis and estimate your income. On the surface, that sounds quite fine. You might not think there is a problem with that. But if you make a mistake of $1 or if there is an overestimation, you have to repay the debt incurred. That is fine. No-one disputes that if you incur a debt you pay it back. But I think the problem here is that currently 32 per cent of family payments are in error. They are in error because it is almost impossible to actually estimate your income from fortnight to fortnight and get it spot on every time. If you do not get it spot on, what is your reward? If you do not get it right with Centrelink, you have to pay back the debt. Okay, so you pay back the debt. What happens when you have to do that? You get less money and that makes it tougher for you. What happens then? Again, life becomes harder. For the 32 per cent of families out there who have incurred a debt of, on average, about $1,000, that is $1,000 less they are going to have. Sure, they had it in the first place, but they have to pay it back. It is always easy to say, ‘You earnt that money. You got that money. We gave that to you, so give it back.’ You hardly notice a couple of dollars a week or a few dollars a month coming in, but you really notice it when it is going out. When it is coming out of your pay and the government says, ‘Give us back our money,’ then we have a real problem.
title: Representatives Main Committee

speaker: Mr Sawford
theText: Tough love!
title: Representatives Main Committee

speaker: Mr Ripoll
theText: Absolutely. It is all about tough love: there is a lot of tough and very littleWednesday, 5 April 2000 MAIN COMMITTEE 15353 Currently there exists a margin for error, because the government has realised that it is not always possible to get it spot on. If you are working overtime, and you are doing those normal things that a family does, then the errors can creep in. But now the government is talking in this bill about ‘zero tolerance’-no 10 per cent margin, no buffer zone. These families are not cheating the system, they are just going in there and honestly trying to estimate. It is almost impossible because you work a couple of hours overtime one week and none the next: it is all over the place. So what happens under zero tolerance? If you are $1 out, you have to pay it back-you incur a debt. So you become a debtor to the government. And if you become a debtor to the government under this bill, you then cannot claim an advance. Again it is every little bit, always that little increment. It is always about ratcheting it up one more level to make it harder and harder. I keep questioning: what is the purpose of this; what are we doing? What is the purpose of handing out a few dollars to some people to try and assist them, and then making it as hard as possible, not only to qualify, to actually get the assistance in the first place, but to maintain it? What zero tolerance means for this government is zero tolerance for families. That is what it is about. Zero tolerance means, ‘We are not going to tolerate your making a $1 error. We are not going to tolerate your making an estimate.’ I always thought that an estimate was just that-an estimate. ‘Can you please give me an estimate of what you think this might be for the next fortnight?’ ‘Well, since it hasn’t happened yet, I will give you an estimate. That estimate might be out by a few dollars, and, sure, I might incur a debt and have to pay it back.’ Why can’t this government look a bit more closely at doing something positive, instead of trying to slug these people with an average debt of about $1,000, which they incurred quite unjustifiably? Again it is all about newspeak by the government: more is less, less is more. There is a range of other parts of the legislation which are quite disturbing. A funny situation arises with regard to the incurring of a debt, in that if you are a high income earner you can make your claim at the end of the year. You do not have to estimate anything; you can actually do it dollar for dollar. You can get the accountant to do it for you. If you are in that comfortable bracket and you are getting a little bit more, you are fine, but in the lower and middle income earners bracket-where the majority of people are and where this debt is actually incurred-people actually need the money week to week. They need those few extra dollars. That is why the dollars are there. So they are the ones that carry the burden. Everywhere you turn in this bill, you find it is quite clear on a number of things such as zero tolerance. And who carries the burden? The burden is shouldered by those least able to afford it. The legislation contains also a number of issues about shared care arrangements. Currently there is a 30 per cent care arrangement with the non-custodial parent, where if you care for the child for 30 per cent of the time, then you get part of the allowance and so forth. The government is going to reduce that to 10 per cent. It is an absolutely ridiculous proposition. There has been no consultation. The Single Mothers Council of Australia has rejected this idea, saying it means that, if you care for the child for one day a week or a little more, you can claim part of the allowance. So the main carer, who might have the child for 90 per cent of the time, suddenly loses money. To wrap up: there is a whole range of issues in here and it would take me hours to go through them one at a time. WhatI would like to say is that this clearly demonstrates the antifamily values of this government. speaker: Mr Emerson (Rankin) (10.18 A.m.)
theText: TheA New Tax System (Family Assistance and15354 MAIN COMMITTEE Wednesday, 5 April 2000 intentions-announced at the election-for the consolidation. I believe consolidation is a step in the right direction, because the overlapping of a plethora of family payments with the tax system has created a lot of complexity. It has also created the problem of high effective marginal tax rates. As benefits are withdrawn with earned income, the tapering effect of that withdrawal rate in relation to a number of the family payments is very high. Also, you are paying income tax on every extra dollar beyond the tax-free threshold. So to obtain the effective marginal tax rate is quite simple: you add together the marginal rate of income tax and the withdrawal rate or the taper rate. Some of those effective marginal rates of tax are quite horrific. The damage that they do is concentrated on lower and middle income families because it has the effect of creating poverty traps, of making the transition from welfare to work that much more difficult because the incentives to move from welfare to work are greatly impaired. Put simply, when someone who is receiving some form of government payment looks at the amount of money they will have in their pockets from making the decision to move from welfare to work or to move from, say, casual or part-time work to full-time work, they realise that there is very little left in their pockets. Quite rationally, in many cases, they make the judgment that it might be better not to take that extra work, not to take that extra job, but to wait for something better to come along because they are able to retain only such a small proportion of income from that extra effort, that extra work. I have to say that some of these high marginal rates or effective marginal rates of tax are, in fact, the result of a number of very good initiatives that were taken by the previous Labor government to increase payments to low income families. I refer in particular to Bob Hawke’s child poverty pledge when he was maligned for setting as a goal-and it was a goal-that no child shall live in poverty by 1990child need live in poverty, and that did not make it into the speech. That is history. But behind that election statement were a huge number of dollars for low income families. It gives me, as a former employee of the then Prime Minister Bob Hawke, great pride to be able to report some of the impacts of that child poverty pledge and other initiatives taken by the Labor government at that time. It is a fact that earnings inequality in Australia widened more sharply over the 20-year period from the mid-1970s to the mid-1990s than in any other OECD country. But this was almost fully offset by the progressive income tax system and government transfers to low income earners, and government transfers to low income earners is really what we are talking about in this legislation. As a result, over that period from the mid-1970s to the mid-1990s, Australia achieved a fall in poverty, as was the intention of the child poverty pledge, which ‘was concentrated in the second decade when Labor was in power’. That quotation comes from Access Economics in a major report that it produced in 1999-just last year. And these findings of Access Economics have been confirmed by the National Centre for Social and Economic Modelling, NATSEM, which found, for the period 1982 to 1993, that: Changes in the tax transfer systems appeared sufficient to fully offset growing inequality of market in-comes, resulting in little change in the aggregate distribution of disposable income. What these two studies reveal is that market incomes did widen quite dramatically over the 30-year period from the 1970s through to the end of the 1990s, but in the latter decades, when Labor was in power, the transfers associated with the child poverty pledge and other commitments to lift up low income families meant that the inequality in Australia overall did not widen in spite of that dramatic, sharply widening gap between the earnings of high income and low income earners. I think it is actually a cause for great pride, on both sides of the parliament, that that was achieved. But what it inadvertently did was that, by piling these extra

speaker: Mr Emerson
theText: In fact, the technical section of the whole documentation said that noWednesday, 5 April 2000 MAIN COMMITTEE 15355 payments on top of each other, the withdrawal rates all compounded, so you did get very high effective marginal rates of tax. It was not an intended consequence; it was unintended. There has been a great opportunity for this government to deal with that problem. Unfortunately, in the legislation, it makes some progress in some areas but, particularly in the area of the unemployed-people on Newstart-very little progress has been made. I refer to the example of an unemployed person receiving Newstart who is offered a job, say, in the range of $10,000 to $15,000 a year, which is quite common; if you have been out of work, it is not highly likely that you will be offered a $50,000 or $60,000 a year job. You may be offered a part-time job, putting a toe in the water so that the employer can have a look at you and you can have a look at the employer. The effective marginal tax rate over that range of $10,000 to $15,000 has been reduced under the legislation from 90 cents in the dollar to 87 cents in the dollar. That is due only to the reduction in the marginal rate of income tax for lower income earners from 20 cents in the dollar to 17 cents in the dollar. So nothing in this legislation involves a reduction in the taper rate for people on Newstart over that income range, which I think is a great pity, because we could really have made some progress for those people. They remain, therefore, very much caught in a poverty trap. The incentive to move from welfare to work, I would argue, is very low when you are sacrificing, effectively, 87 cents in the dollar for every extra dollar of income earned. So an opportunity has been missed. It is quite clear that, on the part of this government, reducing effective marginal tax rates for welfare recipients is not a priority. As I said, this legislation fails to do that for people on unemployment benefits. The government has completely rejected the idea of tax credits. It has rejected, for example, the Keating-Lambert proposal which would have consolidated the payments even further and which would have meant that there was a single taper. That was covered in the Financial Review today. There is some merit in the Keating-Lambert proposal, but the government has said, ‘No, we’re not interested in that.’ I think it does reveal its social agenda. That social agenda is one in which we get the sort of rhetoric and inferences that people on welfare are bludgers. I refer to the words of the employment minister, who regards them as ‘job snobs’. There is this denigration of people on welfare who face effective marginal tax rates of 87 cents in the dollar, and even higher rates in some cases. These people are supposed to be welfare bludgers, but for high income earners who face a marginal tax rate of 48½ cents in the dollar, the government considers that that is a punitive rate of tax and that it removes the incentive to work harder and improve oneself and one’s family. But an effective marginal rate of 87 cents in the dollar is fine for low income earners because it allows the government to continue to label them as ‘job snobs’ and ‘bludgers’. The Treasurer has said, ‘We’ve got to get this top marginal rate of tax down.’ I refer here to statements that he has made. He finds that this is a great disincentive to work and he has declared himself to be an ‘income tax cut man’. He said that in a statement after delivering an address at the forecasting conference of the Economics Society of Victoria on 19 August 1999. That was reported on page 1 of the Australian Financial Review on 20 August 1999. He said that he was an income tax cut man and that he wanted to get the top marginal rate pushed out to be ‘multiples of average weekly earnings’. He said that in an interview on Meet the Press on the Ten Network on 30 May last year. So we have got the Treasurer of this country saying, ‘Oh, that 48½ per cent rate is punitive; it robs people of incentive to work. But 87 cents in the dollar is fine for low income earners because we can continue to label them as welfare bludgers and job snobs.’ Such are the priorities and such is the philosophy of this government. 15356 MAIN COMMITTEE Wednesday, 5 April 2000 The government have said that the tax package, of which this legislation forms part, is going to be magnificent for families. They have now fallen into their own trap of making wildly exaggerated claims about the benefits of this risky tax scheme. The Prime Minister has said on a number of occasions that the average family will receive $47 a week in their pockets. The Deputy Prime Minister went one further-I think there is a bit of an auction going on here-and said in the parliament on 5 February, talking about a single income couple with a baby in Collarenebri on $30,000 a year-a typical family in that little townthat they will have an extra $65 a week in the home to spend. And then, not to be outdone, the minister for workplace relations, Mr Reith, said on 2UE recently, ‘What about an assurance for someone on 30 grand a year who, under us, is going to have $71 a week more in their pocket. For that person on $30,000, $71 a week is a lot of money. That is $3,500 a year.’ So we have the Prime Minister saying $47, the Deputy Prime Minister saying $65 and, not to be outdone, the minister for workplace relations saying an average family is going to get $71 a week. Each and every one of them completely failed to mention the war, the three-letter word-GST. They all failed to mention the GST. What is the latest assertion? Is it that the GST will cost people nothing? I believe that this will condemn them once the GST actually comes in because I reckon that there will be very few Australian families who believe the government when it says, ‘You are $47 a week better off,’ or ‘You are $65 a week better off,’ or ‘You are $71 a week better off.’ They will say, ‘Funny, it does not feel that way.’ So the government is sowing the seeds of its own demise in making these wildly exaggerated claims about the impact of this risky tax scheme. It is a fact that with the GST, every time you have a child you enter into a higher tax bracket because those children consume, and what is being introduced is a tax on consumption. It is a tax on virtually all of the things that babies consume-all of their clothes, all of the services that for the first time are going to be subject to tax. Overall, when you weigh one side against the other you realise that essentially what this legislation is about is an attempt, but not a very good attempt, to compensate families for the impact of the GST. Really, this is compensation. On its own there is merit in it, and we supported the original legislation last year because it did provide extra family payments, but it fails the test of adequately reducing the effective marginal tax rates for low income earners. It has to be seen in the context that it is really an attempt to compensate for the GST, and for lower and middle income families that compensation is not adequate. I ask members of parliament to spare a thought for that other category of people, single people, who are the forgotten people in this tax package because they get very little. It is quite easy to demonstrate that single people on low and middle incomes are going to be clearly worse off under the risky tax scheme that the government is putting in place. Another category of single people is age pensioners. Many age pensioners, obviously, live alone; they have lost their partners. We have had the government saying, ‘But age pensioners are going to receive this bonus of $1,000,’ which in most cases is just untrue. They are going to receive dollar for dollar on any investment income that they have. In my electorate, and in the electorates of the members for Sydney and Melbourne Ports, there are thousands of pensioners who derive no income at all from investments. They have not got any investments because they could never afford to have them. They will not get this $1,000 bonus. The government have been quite misleading before, during and after the election in asserting that as well as getting this $1,000 bonus-which many age pensioners will not get-the age pension is going to go up by four per cent. What they failed to mention, other than in the fine print, is that there will be an initial four per cent in the pension but half of that will be grabbed back on 31 March next year. Half of the four per cent will be clawed back-so there will be a two per cent rise, not a four per cent rise. And this is meant to compensate for all of the price impacts of the GST. Clearly, it will not be able to compensate adequately for that. Wednesday, 5 April 2000 MAIN COMMITTEE 15357 The consolidation of family payment does have merit, but the government has squandered an opportunity to improve the incentives to move from welfare to work. This is just another instalment in widening inequality in the information age. There is a new economic agenda that is only being pursued by one side of politics-and that is the Labor Party. It is part of being the knowledge nation to put extra resources into making sure that young people and older people, through lifelong learning and reskilling, have the skills to be able to compete for jobs successfully in the information age. Over three years, $20 billion of government surplus is being taken from the new agenda and from giving skills to people from disadvantaged areas to pay for the old agenda. The old agenda is a GST. The Australian government said that because Europe has a GST we have to have one. This is the old economic agenda. Labor pursued an economic agenda of microeconomic reform through the 1980s and the 1990s, reducing tariff barriers, deregulating the financial system, floating the dollar and creating more competition in the economy. Most of those measures were supported-sometimes grudgingly-by members of the present government. But the government says there is unfinished business in the old economic agenda. We have to have a GST, which Labor has not supported and has never supported, and we have to have further changes in the industrial relations system to make sure that we can depress the wages of families who are already on low incomes. The government have taken $20,000 million from the new economic agenda, including from education and all those vital social services that would create a proper and decent fair society, and used it to pay for what they consider to be the unfinished business of the old economic agenda. What we face now, as a result of the government’s inaction on the new economic agenda, is a fractured and increasingly unequal society. A fractured society is an unsafe society. If high income earners cannot find the motivation from altruism to pay their fair share of tax and stop engaging in aggressive tax avoidance schemes-more of which we have seen revealed in the last few days-and cannot find in their hearts the altruism to say, ‘We have to pay our fair share of tax so that kids from disadvantaged areas can be lifted up and given a decent education and future,’ they may have to look at the motivation of self-interest and understand that, as income inequality continues to widen and social exclusion becomes more commonplace, this fractured society is becoming an increasingly unsafe society. They are going to have to confront the reality that, if they are to look after themselves and their families, they are going to have to pay their fair share of tax. The government talks about welfare bludgers and job snobs, but it never talks about tax bludgers. The country is full of high income earners who go to all these respectable functions. They present themselves as respectable people in society and yet they are engaged in aggressive tax schemes to minimise tax. If they paid their fair share of tax, they could contribute to the new economic agenda to a fair and more decent society. Ms PLIBERSEK (Sydney) (10.38 a.m.)-I rise to speak on A New Tax System (Family Assistance and Related Measures) Bill 2000. I was struck by the inclusion of the term ‘family assistance’ in the title of the bill. I sometimes wonder whether these bill titles are ironic. The other reminder of the irony of the titling of bills was ‘more jobs, better pay’. While much of this legislation is uncontroversial, there are aspects that will undoubtedly hurt families and, particularly, hurt children. With this bill coming in the week after the release of Jocelyn Newman’s report on welfare reform, people might be forgiven for wondering whether this government’s support for families is no more than rhetoric. The aspect of the bill of greatest concern to me relates to the cut to the family tax benefit for the primary carer when the non-residential parent has more than 10 per cent care of a child. Under previous policy, family payments were shared once there was a minimum of 30 per cent care from the non-custodial parent. That is consistent with child support payments 15358 MAIN COMMITTEE Wednesday, 5 April 2000 which currently recognise that a significant commitment of 30 per cent care is needed by the non-custodial parent before their child support liability is reduced. This legislation proposes that the family tax benefit for the primary carer would reduce as soon as the non-residential parent has 10 per cent care. That is less than one day a week; it is only 36 days a year. It is likely to cause significant hardship for single parents who stand to lose up to $40 per fortnight for each child that is subject to these arrangements. Of course, anyone who has primary care of children realises that your expenses do not necessarily diminish that much if you do not have the children one day a week. You are still responsible for rent, clothing, putting food on the table and all of the ordinary expenses of child rearing. This government is full of talk on how it supports families, yet it looks for any opportunity to take money away from the poorest families. The government has cut child-care assistance, axed retraining programs and severely restricted employment support schemes such as JET, aimed at getting parents back into work. The recent report so paraded by the Minister for Family and Community Services just continues this trend. Patrick McClure, Chief Executive of Mission Australia and the chairperson of the federal government’s reference group on welfare reform, stated quite clearly: Without a fundamental change in the direction of the nation’s social support system, far too many Australians are at risk of long-term poverty. This is one of the findings of the interim report. He is right in saying that the risk of poverty is much too high, but this report and this government have no solutions for that. This minister does not see it as her job to address unemployment and disadvantage, or intergenerational poverty. She sees it as her job to save a few dollars on the budget bottom line, to throw a few single mums off the pension and get those lazy disabled people back down the mines or up the chimneys. To do the job of welfare reform properly, the minister would have to get her government to commit to a program over many years, indeed decades, and to spend billions of dollars to actually get people from welfare to work. Such a program would have to address social and educational disadvantage, parenting skills and, most particularly, support for working families. Welfare reform is not just about saving nickels and dimes; it is about helping people to become independent when they can be and it is about giving security and peace of mind to those people who continue to rely on benefits. Providing support and assistance to sole parents and disability pensioners may be the emphasis of the report but, as Tony Eadley points out, ‘it is underpinned by the government’s veiled threats of compulsion and sanctions’. It reminds me of some of the more punitive measures that were taken up by some of the North American states. In a book called No one left to lie to, Christopher Hitchens says: ... we are endlessly instructed, while rich people will not work unless they are given money, poor people will only work if they are not. (These are the two modern meanings of the term “incentive”: a tax break on the one hand and the threat of the workhouse on the other.) And, once the Democratic party had adopted this theology, the poor had no one to whom they could turn. The immediate consequence of this was probably an intended one: the creation of a large helot underclass disciplined by fear and scarcity, subject to endless surveillance, and used as a weapon against any American worker lucky enough to hold a steady or unionised job. The evidence lies all around us, and will be around us for some time to come. Whether it is gleaned from the most evenhanded and “responsible” reporting, such as that of Jason DeParle atop the great rampart of the New York Times. He goes on to say: ... we shall have to accustom ourselves to stories like this. In Missouri, under the Direct Job Placement scheme (such schemes are always known officially as “initiatives”), the state bureaucracy mutates itself into a hiring hall for cheap labor in junk-nutrition conglomerates such as Tyson Foods. Welfare recipients are told to sign on and gut fifty chickens a minute, or be wiped from the rolls of the new Poor Law. They are directed to an industry which is well used to turnover among employees: Wednesday, 5 April 2000 MAIN COMMITTEE 15359 Here is a story of a particular person affected by these laws. He writes: As one woman on welfare discovered [never mind her name] even having a newborn baby and no means of transportation is no excuse. When the thirty-year-old mother informed her case managers of these extenuating circumstances, they were not sympathetic. “They told her she had to work at Tyson’s even if she had to walk to get there-a six-mile trek,” says Helen Chewning, a former family advocate with the Missouri Valley Human Resource Centre in Sedalia. “They sanctioned her while she was pregnant, and then ordered her to work at Tyson’s when her baby was just eleven days old. She hasn’t had any income for six months. How are they supposed to live?” That, of course, was all reporting from Christopher Cook, but Christopher Hitchens goes on to say: The process of “sanctioning”-the new state euphemism for coercion via the threat of cut-offinvolves facing defenceless people with the rather old choice between “work or starve.” It is the tactic by which welfare rolls are being “trimmed”, if you will allow another Clintonian euphemism. You can be “sanctioned” if you refuse any job, or miss any interview. I did not select Missouri because it’s a famously unsentimental state. I selected it because President Clinton in an August 1997 address to businessmen in St Louis, touted it as the model laboratory for his welfare reform. It’s useful only for dialectical purposes to mention that Tyson Foods uses the Direct Job Placement scheme as its taxpayer-funded recruiting sergeant. The first shock of recognition, experienced by those who are supposed to be grateful for a dose of nonalienated and dignified labor, is the “puller job.” This involves gutting birds-later to provide tasteless nourishment at the tables of the badly off-at a rapid rate. The fingernails of the inexperienced are likely to be the first to go; dissolved in bacteria and chicken fat. Of Missouri’s 103,000 poultry workers, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics, almost one-third endured an injury or an illness in 1995 alone. That this may be an undercounting is suggested by the experience of one hard-pressed toiler on the Tyson chicken-thigh assembly line named Jason Wolfe: “They want you to hang forty or fifty of these birds in a minute, for four to six hours straight, without a break. If you miss any, they threaten to fire you.” He himself was fired because of too many “sick days.” Supplied by the state with a fearful, docile labor force, the workhouse masters are relatively untroubled by unions, or by any back-talk from the staff. Those who have been thus “trimmed” from the welfare rolls have often done no more than disappear into a twilight zone of casual employment, uninsured illness, intermittent education for their children, and unsafe or temporary accommodation. Only thus-by their disappearance from society-can they be counted as a “success story” by ambitious governors, and used in order to qualify tightfisted states for “caseload-reduction credits” from the federal government. The women among them, not infrequently pressed for sexual favors as the price of the ticket, can be asked at random about the number of toothbrushes found in the trailer, and are required by law to name the overnight guest or the father of the child if asked. Failure or refusal to name the father can lead to termination of “benefits” or (an even better word) “entitlements.” Christopher Hitchens goes on to describe in quite a lot of detail what the effects of the American states’ views of mutual obligation have been and, in fact, the deleterious effects that they have had, of course, on the welfare recipients but, perhaps even more importantly, on the children that rely on those parents. Mike Steketee wrote in the Australian of this government’s attitudes towards people receiving welfare benefits that show they have lost touch with the community when they believe that ‘... a strongly performing economy must have opportunities for everyone and those that remain unemployed are bludgers’. He is pointing out that for most people, the vast majority of people, unemployment is not a choice. It is not a lifestyle decision. The government has tightened economic policy at the expense of programs to help the long-term unemployed. The government has clearly betrayed families, contrary to the Prime Minister’s assertion that ‘families are the essential building block of a dynamic and decent society’. If the Prime Minister believes this, it is difficult to understand how 770,000 children now grow up in families where neither parent has a job. When the figures were last taken in 1999, that was an increase of 96,000 people since the election of the government. In a speech 15360 MAIN COMMITTEE Wednesday, 5 April 2000 to the Australian Federation of Childcare Associations in 1997, Senator Newman promised ‘a high quality child-care system ... flexible, affordable and accessible’. Yet, child care under this government has gone up at least $20 a week for most families following cuts of $850 million from the child-care budget. It is obvious that these measures have been responsible for the drop in the participation rate of women in the economy and, certainly, for increased insecurity and cuts to the hours of numbers at work. It is unfortunate that, on the one hand, the Minister for Family and Community Services is undermining every effort of families to return to the work force, particularly burning the bridges that are necessary for single parents to re-enter the work force, and then feels it necessary to punish those people who are suffering from these cuts to programs. Peter Edelman, a US worker in the area of welfare policy, points out that there are class issues involved here. Of a similar situation in the United States, he said: There is a submerged class question here. I always get at it in my speeches by pointing out the hypocrisy in the rhetoric as to who should stay home with their children. Many on the right (and elsewhere) are saying mothers should stay at home with their small children because the new research data on brain development shows that small children need that stimulation. These same people then turn around and say poor moms have to go out and work immediately. (Many states have work requirements beginning when an infant is twelve weeks old, and the vast majority of the remainder require work when a child is a year old. That is a pretty class distinction.. It is interesting as well that this minister who seems to believe that caring for children is not valuable work on its own and who ignores the fact that there are currently 28,000 disabled people on waiting lists for training-these same people that she is saying need to undertake some work tests-manages to claim two pensions herself. On top of her salary as a cabinet minister, the minister is entitled to a parliamentary widow’s annuity and a defence force spouse benefit. Of course there is no reciprocity demanded of her-and nor should there be. She is entitled to these benefits and she claims them. Yet at the same time as she is claiming these benefits she is looking for ways to trim the social security lists. Surely is it obvious that there is some irony here, where people who do not need benefits are allowed to stick their hand out and claim them and those people who are just getting by, who are just managing, are being told to get out there and get off the social security lists. The agenda of the government is based on their view that the disadvantaged, the sick, the disabled, those raising children, the unemployed, the carers and those struggling to survive owe a debt to society rather than that they are Australians who need a hand in unfortunate times. Gerard McEwen of Glandore in South Australia put it very clearly in his letter to the Australian in March this year. He stated that the current government’s definition of mutual obligation is: ... in return for less money than it takes to live, the recipient agrees to be grateful for being humiliated and bullied. Adele Horan, of the Sydney Morning Herald, has suggested a number of times over the last year that one way in which the necessary costs of welfare reform could be found would beand the member for Rankin spoke of it earlier-if the government were willing to crack down on tax dodgers, the big end of town cheats. She said: Where might the money come from to provide the extra Centrelink staff, the social workers and the psychiatrists, the job training and the childcare that the committee sees as prerequisites for many sole parents and disability pensioners to make the transition to work? Who will pay the very necessary increased rate of benefit implied in the report? I think the sad answer is that no-one is going to pay it. This government does not have a commitment to making the investment that is required to get people from welfare to work. To blame those most disadvantaged in society, to penalise them, is wrong. To set up a situation where people are punished for not complying with mandatory work is wrong. To fail to acknowledge that work undertaken by a single mum in caring for her baby is wrong. This Wednesday, 5 April 2000 MAIN COMMITTEE 15361 difference between the Howard government’s rhetoric on welfare and the reality of its policy in action is wrong. Labor’s vision for welfare reform and an adequate welfare system involves acknowledging the work that parents do-the importance of caring for children and for caring for people with disability. We believe that it is necessary to protect people from poverty and destitution. That seems a very obvious thing to say but, given the experience in many states in the United States where these most punitive measures have been introduced, it is not something that modern civilised societies can any longer take for granted. Those social payments that were instituted, very often 60 years ago, during the 1930s, can no longer be taken for granted. There is no assumption that children born into poverty will actually receive a helping hand. There is, in fact, every indication that the trend is being reversed. Labor believes also that we need to give people choices about how they manage their family and work responsibility in early years of child rearing and about the types of activities they undertake to get back into work. There is no point in asking people to weed along railway tracks if that is never going to lead to a real job, if it is going to be a cycle of punishment and humiliation that does not deal at all with the underlying problems that have led to the unemployment in the first place. What we need to do in welfare reform is to help people to move forward and to become independent, rather than just to threaten, bully and harass them, and pull the rug out from under them. (Family Assistance and Related Measures) Bill 2000. In some respects this bill sums up the whole folly of the government’s tax reform proposal. It is some 300 pages long and it has an explanatory memorandum of some 203 pages, so we have over 500 pages of detail. Its development lacked consultation with the opposition subsequent to its introduction, and it amends eight other acts. In some ways it demonstrates, in this drive for simplification around tax reform, actually more complication and more confusion. When we look at the issue of family assistance in the context of the new tax system we have to look also at the question of whether that assistance is in fact fair, reasonable and just, particularly in relation to compensation on the basis of the changes that have been made with respect to the GST. What we see is a number of flawed assumptions that have come in as the basis for how compensation has been worked out, a number of flawed assumptions around the question of what has occurred. We now know that the figure for inflation that was estimated in the first place is not correct-that the impact on inflation and therefore on prices has been underestimated. Beyond that, having seen the development and the consideration of this system in respect of a range of different areas, we know that the price implications for a range of goods and services have been underestimated. That is going to have an impact on Australian families and on the assistance that they require in order to meet their daily bills. In particular I would like to focus, very briefly, on the health area in relation to that, because it has implications for many Australian families. All of us are users of health care products, and, in the circumstances, that area is something that the government has got terribly wrong. The government said continually that health would be GST free, and only recently has it actually started putting a few riders on which products are covered and which are not. When we look at that area we see some very interesting implications. Let us look at the circumstances of people who need family assistance and people on benefits. Often they will be in a situation where they are on pensions such as disability pensions and often they will be sufferers of various types of chronic illnesses. Those who are suffering from chronic illnesses often require health care which involves a range of different products. Some of those will be prescription products, which therefore are GST free, but often they will be products that are not GST free: although they are clearly of medical benefit, they have not

theText: I rise to speak briefly on the A New Tax System15362 MAIN COMMITTEE Wednesday, 5 April 2000 made the poisons schedule as, effectively, products that require supervision by medical practitioners with respect to how they are used and so they will be subject to GST. When you look at the question of people with chronic illnesses, you often find that we are talking about significant amounts of expenditure being required. People with some skin diseases sometimes require a range of different products, including things like specific shampoos to deal with skin conditions, and ointments and creams for those conditions. Many of those products will not be GST free. The estimate from within industry about the price rises expected in these areas is of up to eight or nine per cent on occasions, depending on the product, so it is almost the entire 10 per cent. And the assistance and compensation packages outlined do not take into account the level of requirement for people in those particular sets of circumstances. I have seen letters from members of the community saying that the bills they could be facing over a monthly period could be as high as $150 to $200. The circumstances are that they are going to rise seven to eight per cent. This goes right through to herbal remedies and a range of other products that are used in preventative health care. This government has really only focused on four issues in the preventative area: sunscreen, condoms, personal lubricants and folate. AlthoughI support those four exemptions, there is a range of other products that should be considered, like calcium for people with osteoporosis. So we see with this bill that a range of amendments are required. It is a huge bill and it requires huge adjustment because this system is just not right. It was not right when it was brought in, it has not been right since then in terms of the adjustments that have been made, and I am sure we are going to be seeing many more amendments to this bill right up until 1 July and, also, post the event. First of all, I thank all the members for their contributions to this debate on the A New Tax System (Family Assistance and Related Measures) Bill 2000. Admittedly, many from the other side were misguided. But I would particularly like to thank the members for McPherson, Hughes and Mitchell. This bill is part of the government’s vision for a new tax system. As part of the government’s plan for a new tax system, the structure and administration of family assistance is being recast and simplified with effect from 1 July 2000. This bill complements last year’s tax reform legislation and, in particular, the family assistance package provided primarily by A New Tax System (Family Assistance) Act 1999 and A New Tax System (Family Assistance) (Administration) Act 1999. These acts have already made huge contributions to reducing 12 forms of assistance currently available through the tax and social security system to three new family assistance payments: family tax benefit part A, family tax benefit part B and child-care benefit. The bill refines the existing legislation package to clarify the operations of various aspects of family assistance law, to replace regulation making powers with substantive provisions, to insert relevant savings and transitional provisions and to make miscellaneous technical amendments. It also makes consequential amendments to other relevant legislation. I would like to talk in some detail about some of the provisions contained in the bill. Under the current family assistance arrangements, many matters are dealt with by way of regulation making powers. The bill replaces existing regulation making powers with substantive provisions in the primary legislation. This replacement provision includes claiming, determining and payment of the child-care benefit-CCB-obligations of claimants and approved care services and payments of advances to services. The bill refines and clarifies the operations of the family assistance law and makes some technical and consequential changes to the family assistance law and other Commonwealth acts. The bill contains necessary transition and savings provisions. The bill provides for special benefit recipients who would otherwise not be eligible for family tax benefit or child-care benefit because of the residence rules to access these
