Main Committee adjourned at 12.59 p.m. The following answers to questions were circulated: Health: Hearing Impairment Programs (Question No. 885) Dr Theophanous asked the Minister for Health and Aged Care, upon notice, on 26 August 1999: (1) Will he provide details on the level and effectiveness of Government programs since 1996 designed to deal with hearing impairment within the indigenous community. (2) What funds have been allocated to hearing services since 1996, and what proportion of those funds was used to service the needs of the indigenous community. (3) What proportion of funding for hearing services was used in programs to prevent hearing impairment in Aboriginal children. (4) Will he provide details of hearing impairment programs to prevent the onset of hearing impairment for indigenous children. (5) Is he able to say how long it will be before it will be possible to provide preventative medicine for all newborn indigenous children so that they do not contract hearing impairment diseases. (6) Are future programs proposed to eradicate all acquired hearing impairment from the indigenous communities; if so, what are the details. (1) The Government’s approach to hearing impairment within Indigenous communities is based on recognising the importance of primary health care in preventing ear diseases which may lead to hearing loss, and the provision of hearing services to assist where hearing impairment has occurred. General Primary Health Focus The Department of Health and Aged Care has developed a comprehensive long-term strategic framework for improving Indigenous health. Implicit in this framework is the recognition that there are no easy or quick solutions in the area of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander health. The strategy has four main components: Developing the infrastructure and resources necessary to achieve comprehensive and effective primary health care for Indigenous peoples; Addressing some of the specific health issues and risk factors affecting the health status of Indigenous peoples; Improving the evidence base which underpins the health interventions; and Improving communication with primary health care services, Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander peoples and the general population. Achievement of the first component is primarily through the funding and development of a national network of Aboriginal Community Controlled Health Organisations. As the Aboriginal Community Controlled Health Organisations provide comprehensive primary health care, it is not possible to report on the extent to which resources in any service are specifically committed towards the prevention, identification and treatment of hearing impairment among Indigenous people. The Commonwealth has increased the level of funding provided through the Office of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Health from $130.6m in 1996/97 to $155.2m in 1998/99 with a further increase announced in the May 1999 budget of approximately $100m over the next four years. Hearing Strategy Building on the national network of Aboriginal Community Controlled Health Organisations and in response to recommended goals of the National Aboriginal Health Strategy (1989), the Minister in December 1996 approved implementation of the National Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Hearing Strategy 1995/96 – 1998/1999.
title: Representatives Main Committee

speaker: Dr Wooldridge
theText: The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:The aim is to provide a strategic approach to improving Indigenous hearing health by targeting children 0-5 years through primary health care organisations, with a focus on hearing and broader child health services. The strategy consists of four main elements: Child Hearing Health Sites : 30 Aboriginal Community Controlled Health Organisations were identified as the Child Hearing Health Sites to incorporate hearing screening and treatment into a comprehensive 0-5 year old child health program. Specialist hearing health workers have been employed in some centres to improve coordination and continuity of care between health care and education sectors at the regional level. Equipment and Training : An audiometric equipment and two-stage training program is being provided to Aboriginal Community Controlled Health Organisations funded by the Office of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Health (OATSIH). The equipment and training program is delivered by Australian Hearing Services through a MOU with OATSIH. Since 1996, 466 Aboriginal Health Workers have participated in hearing health training, with 191 Aboriginal Health Workers having completed both stages of the training program; To date, 95 sets of audiometric equipment have been issued to Aboriginal Community Controlled Health Organisations together with an ongoing equipment maintenance and calibration regime. Capital Infrastructure Program : Soundproof testing facilities have been provided in 15 Aboriginal Community Controlled Health Organisations (with a further 14 awaiting completion) to improve access to community based specialist hearing testing facilities. Strategic Research : The Office of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Health in conjunction with the National Health and Medical Research Council (NHMRC) and the Aboriginal community controlled health sector, have undertaken a process to identify agreed best practice evidence based protocols for secondary and tertiary treatment for hearing impairment. This has provided a framework for a more strategic approach to hearing health research which reflects the importance of otitis media and hearing impairment as a key health issue in Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander children. In addition, this shifts the historical focus from medical and epidemiological issues to service delivery and action-oriented research. Two projects in this area have recently been funded through the NHMRC. An evaluation of the hearing services to Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people, involving the Office of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Health and the Office of Hearing Services will be conducted this financial year. (2) As indicated above, it is not possible to identify, from the funding provided to Aboriginal Community Controlled Health Organisations, the proportion going towards Indigenous hearing activities specifically. These services adopt a holistic approach to primary health care of which hearing health is but one component. The 1995/96 Federal Budget allocated $5.7m over four years for the specific Hearing Strategy described above for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander children. Australian Hearing Services (the public hearing services provider) is funded to provide a range of services as ‘community service obligations’ (CSOs). Last financial year total funding for ‘community service obligations’ was $26m. The funding is for the provision of hearing services to Australian young adults and children up to 21 years of age; eligible adults with special needs or living in remote areas; eligible Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander peoples; and for research. It is estimated that 2728 Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people received services from Australian Hearing Services in 1998-99 through the CSO funding. In addition, about 100 applicants (out of a total of 130,000 applications for a Hearing Services Voucher received by the Office of Hearing Services) identified as Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander adults and received hearing services through the Voucher System. These numbers are almost certainly an underestimate because they are derived from self-identification by the client on the Voucher Application Form. (3) As already noted, Australian Hearing Services is funded to provide a range of functions that together are called ‘community service obligations’. Last financial year total funding for ‘community service obligations’ was $26m. The Government currently does not specify how the funding is to be broken down against these groups, but expenditure on all children (including Indigenous people) was approximately $17m in 1998-99. (4) Australian Hearing Services has a full-time National Indigenous Services Manager. In each State and Territory there is a senior audiologist who is the Australian Hearing Services Indigenous Programs Co-ordinator. Each Australian Hearing Services Hearing Centre has a designated Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander contact officer. All of these people work closely with local Indigenous community organisations and individuals. Australian Hearing Services works collaboratively with various government and non-government agencies who are also involved in the provision of services to Aborigines and Torres Strait Islanders. An example of this would be the Australian Hearing Services program of assistance to the Tiwi people on Bathurst Island, where they work closely with the Menzies School of Hearing Research and the Northern Territory Health Department. During 1998-99 Australian Hearing Services audiologists made a total of 260 visits to 97 Indigenous communities and sites. Many of these visits were for a period of up to one week. Specialist audiologists who deal with these children are able to relate to and work with Indigenous individuals and communities, and to have a thorough knowledge of otitis media and its sequelae, especially as it affects Indigenous children. Services are delivered to Indigenous Australians either in a Hearing Centre, or through an extensive outreach program. There is emphasis on working with the family and community to get the best outcomes. Ongoing arrangements for outreach services are negotiated with the community, taking into account the numbers of new and on-going clients who require services, and the level of support required by Aboriginal Health Workers and teachers. Australian Hearing Services also provides appropriate individual and classroom amplification devices. (5) Essentially there is no medicine to absolutely prevent hearing impairment diseases which are the result of the interaction of a complex number of factors. Factors including inadequate accommodation, overcrowding and limited access to clean water, contribute to high rates of cross-infection. Poor diets also place the population at risk because of lower immunity to infection. (6) In addition to the above, in October 1998 the Government, recognising the need for further research in this area of hearing health for Indigenous people, called for expressions of interest to conduct research into the priority areas identified as primary prevention, secondary prevention, social and behavioural factors and surgical issues. The criteria used in the selection process included, in addition to scientific merit and relevance to the objectives of the program, three others specifically identified as relevant to research in Indigenous health. These were the transferability and sustainability of the research and the level of community participation. The two projects recently approved for NHMRC funding include a focus on the major priority areas identified for research including surgical and social/behavioural issues. The first project at $178,840 to be administered by the Kimberley Public Health Unit is to conduct a two-year scientific project; “Evaluation of tympanoplasty in Aboriginal children in WA and factors associated with successful outcome”. The project will evaluate the outcome of operations done to repair ear drums in Aboriginal children and identify factors associated with a successful outcome. The second project at $153,458 to be administered by TVW Telethon Institute of Child Health Research is to conduct a two-year scientific project; “Socioeconomic risk factors and treatment-seeking behaviour for otitis media in the Aboriginal population of Kalgoorlie-Boulder region.” The project will investigate socioeconomic factors predisposing to ear infections and their effect on compliance with treatment in Indigenous populations of the Kalgoorlie-Boulder region. Aged Persons Saving Bonus: Qualification (Question No. 1068) Mr Ripoll asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 6 December 1999: (1) How many aged persons does the Government estimate will qualify for the Aged Persons Saving Bonus component under subsection 12(1) the A New Tax System (Bonuses for Older Australians) Act. Between 15,000 and 20,000 of such persons are estimated to receive the Self-Funded Retirees Supplementary Bonus. Mobile Phones: Contract Complaints (Question No. 1275) Ms Hall asked the Minister representing the Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts, upon notice, on 16 March 2000: (1) Have mobile phone complaints increased by 42% nation-wide in the last twelve months. (2) Do the majority of complaints relating to mobile phones relate to users not being made aware of the terms and conditions of the contracts they have entered into. (3) What action is the Government taking to ensure that users are aware of the terms and conditions of their contracts. has provided the following answer to the honourable member’s question: The Government does not have data on the total number of complaints about mobile phone contracts and therefore cannot confirm whether complaints have increased by 42%. The Government would expect that most complaints would be made directly to the telephone company. Complaints may also be made to the Telecommunications Industry Ombudsman (TIO), the Australian Competition and Consumer Commission (ACCC), and various State and Territory courts and tribunals such as the New South Wales Office for Fair Trading. As the Government is not a party to complaints made to telephone companies, the TIO, the ACCC or State and Territory agencies it is unable to confirm whether the majority of complaints regarding contracts relate to users not being made aware of the terms and conditions. The Department of Communications, Information Technology and the Arts sought input from the TIO and the ACCC regarding complaints related to mobile telephones, and in particular complaints relating to contracts. The Telecommunications Industry Ombudsman (TIO), the body responsible for handling complaints about mobile phones that are not resolved by the telephone company, has supplied the Department of Communications, Information Technology and the Arts with a breakdown of mobile telephone complaints received by them over the last two years: . In the period 1 March 1998 to 28 February 1999 4,782 complaints about mobile telephone services were received by the TIO; and . For the period 1 March 1999 to 29 February 2000 the total number of complaints rose by 22% to 6,150: . Over this period the proportion of complaints related to mobile telephone contracts remained steady at around 63% of all complaints to the TIO. This suggests the increase in complaints to the TIO is probably due to a greater awareness by consumers of the TIO scheme, and not due to increasing problems with mobile contracts. The ACCC has informed the Department of Communications, Information Technology and the Arts that it received 241 complaints regarding mobile telephones for the period 1 March 1998 to 1 March 1999. In the period 1March 1999 to 1 March 2000 the total number of complaints received by the ACCC increased by 13% to 278. The ACCC is not able to say how many of these complaints related to contracts. There are a number of existing safeguards to protect consumers from unfair or misleading contracts: . The Australian Communications Authority (ACA) has made a requirement that all telephone services, including mobile telephone services, that are supplied under a standard form of agreement must be accompanied by a plain language statement outlining the terms and conditions of the agreement.

theText: The Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the ArtsAt present mobile telephones that are supplied on individual contracts do not have to be accompanied by such a statement. . Industry codes of practice developed by the telecommunications industry’s self-regulatory body: the Australian Communications Industry Forum (ACIF). In September 1999 the Communications Law Centre (CLC) released a report into the usage of mobile phones by young people. This work, which was funded jointly by the Commonwealth Government and the Victorian Consumer Credit Fund, found that a large number of young consumers did not fully understand the individual contracts that they were asked to sign. The CLC report recommended that: . All mobile phone contracts should be accompanied by a plain language statement explaining the terms and conditions of the agreement; and . The Australian Communications Industry Forum (ACIF), the telecommunications industry’s selfregulatory body, should develop an industry code of practice that: Incorporates the plain language statement explaining the terms and conditions of the agreement; and Includes a cooling off period, and guidelines allowing consumers to change mobile plans without penalty, other than the reasonable costs of effecting the transfer. The Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts subsequently wrote to the Chief Executive Officer of ACIF on 21 January 2000 to draw its attention to the findings of the CLC report. The Government believes that ACIF, as the telecommunications industry self-regulatory authority, is the appropriate organisation to develop a code of practice for mobile telephone contracts. If ACIF chose not to develop a code of practice for mobile telephone services the Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts may issue a Direction to the Australian Communications Authority to develop a compulsory code of practice that all telephone companies must adhere to.
